I will next deal with the estimated expenditure .for 1907-8. The following table shows the estimated expenditure as compared with that estimated last year -

Honorable members will not be surprised to learn that a considerable amount has been provided for the current year. The total expenditure last year amounted to £4,987,30.1, whereas the estimated expenditure for the current year is £5,967,992, showing an increase of £980,691. I will enumerate the principal items of increase, and then make some remarks concerning them. The increase on account of sugar bounty amounts to £244,407 ; other bounties, £25,000. On account of the transcontinental railway route survey, I have put down £15,000, as I do not think it is possible for the full amount of ,£20,000 to be spent during the year. Increases on account of votes are as follow : - Meteorological branch, £15,996; works and buildings - maintenance - £33,509 ; quarantine, £8,500.

talk.start.para: - That is very low.

- The reason why I have put down that sum, on the recommendation of my officers, is because it is not estimated that' more than that amount will be required this year. But it is desirable to point out that the whole of that amount, or nearly the whole of it, is merely expenditure transferred from the States to the Commonwealth. It is not an increase in the true sense of the term. We are taking over quarantine, and we have to provide for expenditure on account of it, but the States will be relieved to that extent. Other increases are - in the Customs Department, £17,449; in the Defence Department, £89,514.
- Is that the increase?

- Yes; I will show the reason for it presently. The increase on account of the Post and Telegraph Department amounts to ,£181,891. The increase for additions, new works, and buildings, including special defence provision, amounts 'to £347,093.
- Does that include the naval proposals of the Government?

- Yes. I have already dealt with the subject of the sugar bounty. In regard to the bounties included in the Bill being considered by Parliament, it is estimated that about ,£25,000 will be spent during the current year. My officers have furnished me with that estimate. Next year probably the full amount contained in the schedule approved by Parliament will be expended. I wish to add in connexion with the sugar bounty - and the ex-Treasurer will know very well what I am referring to - that the States get back three-fourths of the excise received by the Commonwealth Government on account of sugar. That, I admit, is a point which had escaped me before I came to look into the subject in preparing the Budget. The Federal Government has to pay the whole of the bounty, but the States receive back three-fourths of the excise collected by us.
- I pointed that out a couple of years ago.
- It has been pointed out a hundred times that the fact to which the Minister refers embarrasses our finances.

- It does very much. I have included ,£1 5,000 for the survey of the transcontinental railway route. It is possible that the whole amount voted by Parliament will be spent during; the current financial year, but I think it probable that it will be found impracticable to finish the survey during the ensuing twelve months.
- It is impossible to do it.

- I think so. I believe that I have made a fairly liberal' estimate on that account. The amount of £15,996 is provided for the new Meteorological Branch. The undertaking; of that work by the Commonwealth is also a relief to the States. It transfers expenditure from them, and involves additional expenditure by the Commonwealth. By separating the meteorological work from the work proper to astronomical observatories, and by making it a special branch of study, it is hoped that research will be carried out in a much more effective manner, and that in the end practical1 results of great importance will accrue.. It is also considered that it will be an> advantage to the States Government Astronomers to be able now to concentrate their energies on their own special work. As the expense of the various meteorological stations was previously borne by the States, there is really .no new expenditure involved, the. burden being merely shifted from the States to the Commonwealth. With regard to works and buildings, the increase of £33,509, under that heading is spread over all the States. I will not take up the time of the Committee by enumerating the amounts. Provision has beén made for sanitary work in Sydney demanded by the Board of Health on account of the plague. In consequence of the erection of a number of new' post-office buildings and telephone exchanges, and the establishment of the meteorological bureau, a considerable amount - say, £8,500 - has been provided; . for fittings and furniture. Provision for new boilers for naval boats, and for repairs, has been made, amounting to£5,000. Many urgent services, authorized during the last financial ' year, were not carried out, and provision has been made in this . year's Estimates for carrying out works authorized in the previous year amounting altogether to £60,847. These are all set out in the column of the Estimates headed " Revotes." The sum of £8,500 has been provided for the expenses of quarantine. This is not a new expenditure; it simply represents a transfer from the States to the Commonwealth. With regard to the increases in the Customs expenditure, amounting to £1 7,449, an extra sum of £5,640 has been provided to reimburse the States the cost of carrying out the provisions of the Commerce Act. Last year only £6,282 was expended, but as that was in respect of a period of only nine months, a sum of £11,922 in all has been provided under this heading for the present financial year. I should like to explain that this arrangement will give relief to the States. We have taken over the States officers engaged in carrying out this work, and have become responsible for the payment of their salaries, so that we are thus taking a burden from the States and placing it upon our own shoulders. The advantages which are accruing from the Commerce Act are so great that I am sure there will be no disposition on the part of honorable members to object to this expenditure. It has been found necessary to strengthen the Customs Department in New South Wales, the additional expenditure, inclusive of contingencies, being a little over £5,000. The remaining increases, amounting to £4,000, will be found distributed amongst the branches of the Department in the various States. I have already said that the increase in the cost of the Defence Department, as compared with the actual expenditure last year, will be £89,514. But if honorable members will refer to page 74 of the Estimates they will see that, comparing the Estimates of 1906-7 with those of the current year, the addition to the cost of the Department will be only £24,000, which is accounted for by increased expenditure in respect of rifle clubs and cadets. I should like to impress upon honorable members the point that the total increase will come under those two headings. The increased provision for cadets includes £12,402 for additional personnel; £4,898 for camps of instruction, and £2,000 for rifle meetings. The increase in the vote for rifle clubs includes the sum of £1,000 granted to the council of the Commonwealth Rifle Association to meet expenditure in connexion with the visit of a rifle team from Great Britain. I am sure that honorable members will not object to that expenditure.

speech.para: Honorable Members. - Hear, hear !

talk.start.para: - A proportion of that grant will be distributed among each of the States to be visited by the team. The increase in the vote relates also to increased railway fares and ammunition and increased grants to the Rifle Associations. I am happy to state that the membership of rifle clubs increased by 5,817 during the last financial year. The number of Australians serving under the Naval Agreement is 651, including 128 men from New Zealand. These are serving in the Challenger, the Pioneer, the Psyche, and the Pyramus. Forty-one of them, consisting of thirty-one Australians and ten New Zealanders, have been sent to England to undergo a twoyears' course of training, in order to qualify for higher ratings. Upon their return, "they will be given petty officer ratings on the ships of the Australian Squadron. In the Australian branch of the Royal Naval Reserve 310 Australians and 67 New Zealanders are enrolled. Honorable members will probably be surprised at the large increase in expenditure in the Postal Department. It must be remembered, however, that this is not a stationary Department. It is a progressive and growing service. The revenue of the Department has increased from £2,372,000 in 1901-2 to £3,129,000 in 1906-7. Notwithstanding a prospective loss of £117,000 owing to the introduction of penny postage, it is estimated that for the current year the revenue will be £3,190,000.
- We have not yet decided to suffer a loss by the introduction of penny postage.
- That is so.
- It would not be: a loss. We should simply refuse to take the sum mentioned out of the pockets of the people.
- I hope that my, honorable colleague will restrain himself.

speech.para: If the Parliament is to provide for the growing demands of the public for telephonic and telegraphic conveniences in connexion with the great expanse of trade that is taking place, then a considerable increase of expenditure is inevitable. That this increase in expenditure is not peculiar to the Commonwealth may be seen by comparing the present expenditure of the States with that of six years ago. I would direct special attention to the fact that the total expenditure of the States, including interest on loans, was increased by about £4,250,000 during the period 1899-1900 to 1905-6, which is the last year in respect of which audited figures are available. Carping critics who declare that our expenditure is increasing very rapidly, will recognise from these figures that there is really no substantial foundation for complaint. We have taken over so many services previously carried out by the States, that our expenditure has necessarily increased. The States, on the other hand are, so to speak, self-contained, and have not had to embark upon such new expenditure as has been unavoidable in connection with the establishment of the Commonwealth. As regards the mail contract, I merely wish to state that the Government regrets the long delay which has' taken place. Although it was felt that it would be greatly to the advantage of the Commonwealth if the arrangement entered into with Sir James Laing and Sons were carried out, we could not but recognise that more than ample time had been given to the contractors to carry out their part of the undertaking. When the Prime Minister and I were in London, we came to the conclusion that the contract should either be carried out or cancelled. Instructions have been given that every step that can be taken legally to enforce the payment of the bond of £25,000 shall be taken'.

talk.start.para: - Has the honorable gentleman included that £25,000 in his Estimates of revenue for the current financial year?

- I have not, but believe that the money will be obtained. I think it possible that there is another item in respect of which a claim may be made. I am not sure on the point, because I could not obtain definite information with regard to it this afternoon, but the Minister of Trade and Customs may be able to . enlighten me on the subject. In my opinion we should insist upon the contractors meeting every liability that they have incurred in connexion with the contract.

speech.para: Honorable Members. - Hear, hear !

talk.start.para: - Tenders have been invited for a new mail contract, and care has been taken that no delay shall occur in the execution of the contract without the imposition of a heavy penalty.
- Which can be recovered, I hope.

- We will see about that when we enter into a new contract. There is no doubt that past experience will make the Government very careful in connexion with another contract; and I am sure honorable members will admit that the object of the Prime Minister and the Postmaster-General, in entering into the previous contract, was to save money for the Commonwealth, and get a more extensive service than we have at the present time. Correspondence is in progress with the States Governments on the subject of cold storage. Quick passages, which are essential to the interests of the mercantile community, will be insisted upon. In order to cope with the largely increased business, especially in the telephone branch of the Postal Department, it has been found necessary to considerably augment the staff. I own that. I was astonished at the large amount provided for in the draft Estimates first submitted to me; but I am glad to say that in pursuance of my instructions to the Department, they have been materially cut down. The total expenditure provided for is £2,805,277 for the post-office alone, as against £2,646,201 provided and ,£2,623,386 expended last year, the increase in the estimate for 1907-8, and the expenditure for 1906-7, being £181,891. In New South Wales there is an increase under the head of " General Contingencies " of £20,000, this being for the purchase of 1,000 water-proof capes, extra travelling expenses, sorting English and foreign mails on the trains between Sydney and Melbourne, conversion of non-official post-offices, purchase pf motor vehicles, and so forth. In Victoria there is a similar increase of £32,926, this being for telephone maintenance work, larger payments to the Railway Department, new regulation in respect to Sunday pay, a higher rate for bicycle contract, higher price of coal and firewood, opening new offices, &c In Queensland in contingencies, there is an increase of £10,629, being a general increase in telephone maintenance works and business generally ; and in South Australia there is an increase, in contingencies, of £7,903 for purchase of motor vehicles and increased business generally. Under the Estimates for Tasmania, an item of £8,781 appears as the amount payable under the guarantee to the Eastern Extension Australasia and China Telegraph. Company. I may explain that in order to promote telegraphic communication between Tasmania and the mainland, the ½d. rate charged for the transmission of telegrams across the Straits, was abolished on the 1 st October, 1906. Under an agreement between Tasmania and the Telegraph Company, the latter was guaranteed a revenue from message receipts - namely, for payment for transmission across the Straits - of £5,600 per annum. Up to the time when the rate was abolished, the revenue received by the Company had been in excess of the amount of the guarantee. In consequence of the abolition of the charge, it is now necessary to pay the Company the full amount of £5,600 per annum. Including arrears, the sum of £8,781 appears on the Estimates for the purpose. That the abolition of the cable rate of½d. per word has had the effect of largely, increasing the telegraph business between Tasmania and the mainland, is evidenced by the fact that during the six months ended 30th September, 1906,. the sum of £9,236 was received for messages, exclusive of cable charges, whilst for the six months ended31st March, 1907, £11,933 was received, showing an increase of receipts of £2,797 in the half-year. Although the increase was partly due, perhaps, to increased prosperity, much of it was doubtless owing to the reduction in the rate.
- There is always an increase in the summer time, in any case.
- There is no doubt about that.
- I think the person originally responsible for that statement should have remembered that there is always an increase in the summer.
- I may also draw attention to the item of £1,000 included under " New Works and Buildings " for the survey of a cable route between Tasmania and the mainland.
- Is that cable going to Twofold Bay?

- I do not think so. It is intended, should Parliament approve, that the Commonwealth shall in the future have a cable of its own, so that no difficulty can arise in consequence of the cable being owned by a private company. speech.para: In explanation of the large increase asked for under " New Works and Buildings," I would remind the Committee that since the establishment of Federation, the Commonwealth Parliament has resolutely set its face against loan expenditure, thus necessitating the expenditure of considerable sums out of revenue, which would otherwise be charged to loans. Of course, that is a state of things, I think, which will not continue indefinitely, as, in the event of the Commonwealth undertaking extensive defence works, and works such as the transcontinental railway, it will be found absolutely necessary to have recourse to loan expenditure.

talk.start.para: - I hope defence works will always be paid for out of revenue.

- I do not think that is possible. I am speaking from a practical stand-point, and I hope honorable members will not think that I desire to see this expenditure out of loans. But I know from past experience that defence works sometimes entail very heavy expenditure.
- The Minister ought to wait until war occurs before he talks about loan expenditure.
- We wish to have insurance against war.
- And we can provide that insurance out of revenue.

- Honorable members, I am sure, will agree with me that a time of abundant revenue is the most opportune for expenditure of a nonrecurring nature, and they will find in the Estimates for new works and buildings a considerable amount of expenditure of this character. Under the control of the Department of Home Affairs, the amount of £221,824 is provided, this being an increase of £131,372 on the expenditure of last year. Provision has been made for underground tunnels for telephone wires, £1 2,000 ; alteration to General Post Office, Sydney, £7,000; telephone exchanges, New South Wales, £4,000 ; alterations to General Post Office, Melbourne, £19,000; telephone exchange, Melbourne, £8,000 ; telephone exchange, Windsor, £6,000 ; extension, General Post Office, Brisbane, £17,000; telephone exchange, Adelaide, £8,000 ; Customs House, Fremantle, £7,500, the total estimated cost being £10,000 ; and purchase of land for rifle" range, Sandy Bay. Tasmania, £4,495. In the Postmaster-General's Department, £300,000 is provided for telegraphs and telephones, this being an increase of £78,301 on the expenditure of last year. Provision has also been made for the con-' struction of conduits and the placing . of wires underground in each of the capitals. A sum of £16,000 is provided for switch boards and additional equipment for a central exchange, Sydney, and £10,000 has been again provided this year for wireless telegraphy. The increase in the portion of the new works and buildings vote, under the control of the Postmaster-General, is altogether £78,301. I now come to a very important and interesting part of the Estimates, namely, the provision made in the new works portion of the Estimates for Defence. Under the Special Defence Material vote last year, £169,156 was. voted, and the expenditure was £159,988. This year it is proposed to expend £104,050 besides making further provision of £29,000 for field artillery, £10,000 for cadet rifles, £20,000 for Martini Lee-Enfield rifles, and £8,000 for camp equipment. A new vote of £18,750 is asked for 25,000 sword bayonets and scabbards for short rifles, these short rifles and bayonets being considered the most effective of modern weapons for the purpose.
- It was stated in the newspapers that the Government were going to convert the bayonets that we already have.

- The honorable member should not take too much notice of what appears in the newspapers. Negotiations were carried on in London between the Prime Minister and the First Lord of the.: Admiralty with regard to the establishment of harbor and coastal defence in Australia, and also the payment of the naval subsidy. I am not aware of the full details of these negotiations, and would prefer that the Prime Minister himself should submit his views to the House with full details.

talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - The Treasurer is not aware of the full details of the negotiations, notwithstanding that he came back: in the same steamer with the Prime Minister ?
- I did not ask him everything that was in my mind.
- A good deal of what the Prime Minister did is disclosed in the document referred to.

- Then there is no necessity for me to repeat it. I have accordingly provided in my Budget proposals for the contribution of the usual' £200,000 a year to the Imperial Navy. A sum, to which I I will now refer, is the amount which has been placed upon the Estimates for the . purpose of commencing the establishment of a coastal' defence Navy. . There is no doubt that an effective coastal defence schemer can be carried out only by the expenditure of a considerable sum of money, but I feel sure that the policy of having such! a protection will commend itself to all who consider that Australia should at least protect itself from the incursion of hostile cruisers. We know how uncertain it is where the British Fleet would be stationed in time of war, and certainly Australia should be in a position to prevent its ports being blockaded or bombarded, or its commerce destroyed by perhaps one or two comparatively insignificant cruisers. There is a sum of £32,000 provided for a factory for manufacturing our cwn small .arms and ammunition, which policy, I am sure, will appeal to honorable members. The following amounts have accordingly been provided on the Estimates : - Towards harbor and coastal defence, £250,000; small arms factory, £32,000 ; cordite factory, £10,000 ; guns, lights, and emplacements for fixed defences, £50,000; total, £342,000. My honorable colleague, the Minister of Defence, desired these items to be placed in this way upon the Estimates, and being of a good-natured disposition, I agreed to his request. I have placed there " Less amount which it is anticipated will not be expended in the year, £125,950," leaving a balance of £216,050. The amount of £32,000 included for the establishment of a small arms factory represents approximately half the cost of the undertaking according to the latest estimates that have been received. The plant would provide for the local manufacture of magazine rifles, cadet rifles, revolvers and bayonets in sufficient quantities for all requirements. It is expected that the factory will be able to turn out about 20,000 rifles per annum.
- Has the Treasurer made up his mind about the site yet?

- No; that is a Cabinet matter. The question has been raised as to whether this factory will not be useless iri a short time. My answer to that is that it will be a good thing if we are able to manufacture more rifles than we want, because then perhaps we may supply those weapons either to Great Britain or some other part of the world. £TO,000 has also been provided for the establishment of a cordite factory, and the erection of the same. Mr. Hake, Chief Inspector of Explosives in Victoria, is now in England making inquiries and obtaining the latest information on the subject- of service explosives. It is anticipated that as the result of his inquiries the defects previously experienced will be overcome, and it will be found that all our requirements in cordite can be met locally. Figures in detail are not yet available, but £10,000 will be all that will' be required this year. With reference to the ,£50,000- for guns, lights, and emplacements, the Imperial Defence Committee have recommended that the armament of the fixed defences of the Commonwealth should, as far as possible, be uniform, the gun to be used being 6-inch mark 7. The Committee of local officers appointed to consider the question agreed with the recommendation of the Imperial Defence Committee. The total cost of the recommendations of the Imperial Defence Committee, including the electric lights, will be about ,£280,000.
- Is it proposed to get rid of the 9.2 guns at Sydney Heads?
- I do not know that it is. We are not proposing to get rid of them, but the Admiralty have made some suggestion of the sort.
- It seems a very foolish thing to get rid of good guns like those.

- So. I informed the First Lord of the Admiralty. Honorable members are aware that under the present system of accounts, the expenditure of the Commonwealth is under two headings: one being "transferred" expenditure - that is the expenditure incurred for the maintenance and continuation of the Departments transferred from 'the States to the Commonwealth - and "other" expenditure - that is new or original expenditure on the part of the Commonwealth. Last year the "other," or new, expenditure amounted to ,£1,236,148, but deducting from that sum the provision for new works in the transferred Departments, which in ordinary circumstances would be charged to loans, and which totalled ,£472,139, New Guinea £23,626, sugar bounty and expenses _£335>9 16, repatriation of Pacific Islanders £8,015, conveyance of mails between Victoria and Tasmania £7,000, guarantee to Eastern Extension Company for the abolition of message receipts, £1,551, making a total of £848,247, we find that the net amount was £387,901, or equal to is. io|d. per head of the population. If we treat the amount estimated for the current year, namely, .£1,908,654, in a similar manner, and deduct provision for new works, transferred Departments £817,874, New

speech.para: Guinea £25,000, sugar bounty and expenses £580,323, repatriation of Pacific Islanders £6,500, conveyance of mails between Victoria and Tasmania £13,000, guarantee to Eastern Extension 'Company £8,781, bounties ,£25,000, non-recurring expenditure £15,000, or a total of £1,491,478, we find that the net expenditure will be £417,176, or equivalent to 2s. per head of the population. 1 think I have now dealt with the expenditure at sufficient length. The following tables will, however, be useful to honorable members : -

One effect of the imposition of the new duties will be that this year the State Treasurers will receive much larger surpluses than they would otherwise have done. Under section 87 of the Constitution, the expenditure of the Commonwealth is limited to one-fourth of . the Customs and Excise revenue, the corollary to which is that the States must receive three-fourths of such revenue.

This state of things will last until the termination of the ten years period on the 31st of December, 1910. I consider that this provision in the Constitution places the Federal Treasurer in an exceedingly difficult position, and I shall point out later on when I deal with our prospective ' requirements', how seriously the Commonwealth is hampered -by the operation of "this clause. I may also remind the Committee that, as the period of five years fixed by clause 94 of the Constitution, which defined the manner in which the surplus revenue was to be handed to the various States, has expired, it is not necessary that such surplus revenue shall be handed to the State Treasurers according to the system of debits and credits we have hitherto been accustomed to. In fact, I am advised that, by Act of Parliament, these conditions can now be varied in a manner which will be advantageous to the Federal Treasurer. It is estimated that the following amounts will be paid over : -

It is estimated that in the current year the States will receive £65,550 less than last year. They will also receive £103,992 more than the three-fourths of the net Customs and Excise revenue which is secured to them by section 87 of the Constitution. Last year the amount of £805,766 was returned in excess. The figures for 1907-8 are :

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - The honorable gentleman's figures show that we are over the limit by £250,000.
- No. As I have shown, the States will receive £103,992 more than the three-fourths of the net revenue returnable to them under the Braddon section.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - We ought to pay them £350,000 in respect of the properties which have been transferred to us.

- I shall deal with that matter in its proper place. I have previously referred at some length to the operation of the Braddon clause, and to its hampering effect on the Federal Treasurer. We have, in the future, also to provide for the payment to the States for transferred properties, to which I shall afterwards refer, for the- development of the Northern Territory and Papua, and for old-age pensions. Further expenditure will, doubtless,, be necessary for the transcontinental rail- way, for quarantine, and the Meteorological Bureau. This year I provide only £25,000 for bounties, and the annual expenditure will be a much larger amount. In reference to the question of payment to the States for transferred properties, I have not had time, nor is it yet necessary, to fully consider the matter. The valuation of properties is proceeding rapidly, and will soon be completed. A scheme must be devised to arrange for equitable payments.
- Will account be taken of what the States have already received ?

- That is a mat,ter which must be dealt with when I consider the subject in detail. It has been quite impossible for me to deal with large problems during the. short period that I have been Treasurer, but the State Treasurers may be satisfied that they will be fairly dealt with in this important matter. The estimated population of the Commonwealth, on 31st December,. 1906, was 4,119,481, as shown in the following table-

speech.para: Since the establishment of Federation there has been a total estimated increase of only 354,142, the annual rate of increase being 1.5 per cent. That this condition of things is satisfactory, I think no one will admit. We cannot but realize that, whilst Canada has, by judicious land legislation and a great expenditure in advertising its resources, succeeded in attracting a very large number of settlers, from Great Britain especially, Australia has been somewhat supine in the matter. With such a large coast-line to guard, and with such formidable neighbours, it certainly behoves us to do what we can in the .direction of filling up this great continent with a suitable, industrious, and thriving population.

talk.start.para: - We shall have them . walking about doing nothing.

- That is not ray intention. Although it is eminently desirable that a large population shall, be settled in Australia, I am of opinion that we should be careful that the class of immigrant we attract to our -shores is a desirable one. I think that before we take any important steps in the direction of inducing them to leave their present surroundings and try their fortunes in a new country, we should know that land is available in the various States, and that proper arrangements are made for meeting them on arrival, and every facility given to them to select their land. It is, however, hoped that arrangements will shortly be made so that the Commonwealth Government can co-operate with the State Governments in this direction. Accordingly, a sum of £20,000 has been placed on the Estimates to further this policy, so desirable in the interests of Australia Last year, only £5,000 was voted, so that we now propose a large increase, but I wish that a larger sum were available. Whilst in London, at the instance of the Prime Minister, I selected a site which appeared to me a very convenient one for the Commonwealth Offices in London. It appears to me desirable that, if possible, we should induce the State Premiers to centralize their London staffs in one building, and for that building to be fairly in the centre of traffic. I have accordingly proposed a most suitable site in the Strand, and a sum of £2,000 appears on the Estimates for expenditure in connexion therewith. The reason that only £2,000 has been placed on the Estimates at present is that for a time only incidental and preliminary expenses will be incurred. If the site to which I have referred is obtained, and I have the offer of it for about six or seven weeks, and of another area in this particular place, we shall pay nothing at all for the first year, and shall not pay the full rent until five years have elapsed.
- Is it the ground rent that will be payable?
- Yes, the ground rent upon . a ninety nine years' lease. It is impossible to buy the land, because it is not for sale.
- What is the value of it?
- I would rather not say at present, because negotiations are still going on. I know what Mr. Bent paid for a part of the land, and a portion of it was offered to me at the same, rate.
- Is it not the intention .that there should be the one building for the States and the Commonwealth ?

- Yes ; that is certainly intended. In this connexion let me say that I was never more disgusted with anything in my life than I was with the difficulty I had to find the offices of the Australian States in London. They are scattered through the city. I was in only two of them, though I looked for three or four others. I think it is quite time that some better arrangements were made and a proper office established, not only for the representatives of the States, but also for the Commonwealth High Commissioner. I feel that the appointment of such an official cannot be very much longer delayed.
- Has the honorable gentleman made provision for the appointment ?

- No; that will be done in a special Bill. Honorable members who know the site to which I refer will not be surprised when I say that it was by far the most suitable place for the purpose that I saw when in London. Of course, the proposed offices when established, will be available for the High Commissioner. of the Commonwealth, and his staff. If the proposal is accepted a building will, of course, be erected. The site belongs to the London County Council, and if the States Governments do not avail themselves of the opportunity which will be afforded them to establish their offices in the building, the accommodation provided can Be easily sub-let until they have decided to do so.
- Did the honorable gentleman say that the site belongs to the London County Council?

- Yes ; they resumed the land and took down the buildings that were erected upon it. The land is now vacant, and the London County Council are making a new street there. No provision has been made on the Estimates for the development of the Northern Territory. I take it that nothing can be done in this matter until the Commonwealth Parliament and the State Parliament of South Australia come to an agreement as to the cession of the Territory to the Commonwealth. It is well known, however, that provisional arrangements have been made with the Premier of South Australia for the Commonwealth to take over the Territory under certain conditions if Parliament concurs. Dealing with affairs in Papua, I may say that Judge Murray is at present acting as Administrator, and Mr. Staniforth Smith is attending to agricultural matters in that territory. The whole subject of the future administration of Papua is under consideration, and will .be dealt with as expeditiously as possible. I do not propose to say very much on the subject of banking legislation, but I certainly intend, if time permits, to deal with the subject. My late colleague, the ex-Treasurer, gave it much thought, and put his ideas concerning it into type.
- I did not settle the question.

- I aim quite aware of that. No doubt the right honorable gentleman gave very great thought to this important matter, and when I come to deal with it, and with some other questions, I shall be very glad if he will give me the benefit of his experience and ideas in framing a good banking Bill.
- I shall be very glad to assist the honorable member.
- Does the honorable gentleman suggest the establishment of a State bank?

- I think it will be something approaching a State bank. I may tell honorable members that when in London, and when I had no idea that I should be placed in my present position as Treasurer, I had the privilege of an invitation to lunch with the Governor and Directors of the Bank of England.
- That is not a State bank ; it is a private bank.

- An offshoot of that bank is practically a State bank. It so happened that the Governor of the Bank of England had a- copy of the Banking Bill drafted by my right honorable friend the ex-Treasurer, which had been sent to him by the right honorable gentleman.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - Things have evidently gone very far.
- I did not know of it before.
- That was all confidential.

- Of course, and I am satisfied that it was a very good thing for' the ex-Treasurer to do, as honorable members will find, when they know what the opinion of the authorities of the Bank of England was in regard to the matter. The Governor of the Bank of England was informed that I had been a member of a Ministry that had a good deal to do in New South Wales with the question of banking at the time of the banking crisis in 1893, and I had a long conversation with him, which will be of very great assistance to me when I come to deal with the question.
- What revenue does the honorable gentleman expect to get from the issue of the Treasury notes proposed ?

- Perhaps the honorable member will ask me that question later on. With reference to old-age pensions, like my colleague, the Minister of Trade and Customs, I. have always taken a great interest in the proposed Federalization of old-age pensions, and as my record, at any rate, in New South Wales, shows, I have always been prepared to make an onward step towards providing for such pensions as early as possible. Once the Tariff has been sufficiently mastered in this House, I intend to devote myself to the examination of the possibilities in this direction, of which Parliament will be duly informed. I hope that the money can be found for the establishment of a Federal scheme at once, because the matter is one which cannot be allowed to rest. Honorable members will admit that stepping into the Treasury Department as I have done, and having to find such a large amount of money, I have not had time up to the present to consider any practical scheme. I wish, however, to remind honorable members that before the election last year, an attempt was made by the Government to secure a referendum for the alteration of the Constitution to provide for the imposition of special duties for the purpose of old-age pensions. That attempt was defeated in the Senate by only one or two votes, but where there is a will there is a way, and the question is one of such great importance, that if I cam possibly bring about the establishment of a Federal old-age pension scheme, it shall be done.
- I hope the honorable gentleman will put the Opposition to the test, and see if they are in favour of old-age pensions.

- At the recent Conference in London, the Prime Minister was informed that there would be no objection raised on the part of the Imperial Government to a special silver and bronze coinage for Australia. The Prime Minister is still in communication with the Imperial authorities, who have been asked to facilitate the displacement of the present coinage. It may be confidently anticipated that, at an early date, this matter will be settled, and the Commonwealth will receive the profit on the Australian coinage. I was present when that statement was made, . and it was emphasized in a way that showed that the Imperial Government fully intended that we should be allowed to carry out what we desire in this respect.
- It will mean ?. profit of only about £25,000.

- That would be something. Five Conferences have now been held with the Premiers of the States' in order to come to an understanding as to the best method of arriving at the surplus to be paid over by the Commonwealth Treasurer to the States after the termination of the operation of the Braddon section of the Constitution, and also to assist the Treasurer in making arrangements for. the transfer of the debts of the States to the Commonwealth. At the Hobart Conference, in 1905, it was agreed to by the Commonwealth representatives, and by a majority of the States, that the Braddon section should remain in operation until 1930, that the whole of the States debts should be taken over by the Commonwealth, and that the States should cease to borrow outside of Australia except through the Commonwealth. At the Sydney Conference, held twelve months later, the States' representatives passed resolutions stating that in their opinion the Braddon section should be operative for all time, and that the Commonwealth surplus revenues should be divided among the States on a population basis. On this latter question, the Premiers of New South Wales and Victoria dissented; Western Australia was not represented. At the Sydney Conference, it was also agreed that the time was ripe for the Federal Parliament to consider the question of taking over the States' debts, in accordance with section 105 of the Constitution. In October, 1906, a Conference was held in Melbourne, at which my predecessor, the right honorable member for Swan, brought forward certain proposals. The State representatives passed the resolutions which follow -

item.para: The Constitution to be amended to provide for payments to the States of a fixed annual amount based on the three-fourths of the net revenue from Customs and Excise up to 1910.

A payment in addition to such fixed amount to be made to bring the aggregate payment' to the States up to three-fourths of the net Customs and Excise Revenue - such additional payment to be distributed per capita.
The Commonwealth to have the right to impose new duties for specific purposes, and to retain the whole of the revenue raised thereby.

speech.para: The Conference also expressed a general approval of the ex-Treasurer's scheme for taking over the whole of the States debts, and left the discussion of the details to a future Conference. Two months ago, another Conference was held in Brisbane, when the following proposals were agreed to by the Premiers -

item.para: From 1910 until 1920, and thereafter until

speech.para: Parliament otherwise provides, the 'States to receive a fixed annual sum based on the average of three-fourths of the net Customs and Excise revenue during certain years.

item.para: The States to receive a payment in addition to such fixed amount to bring the aggregate payment to the States up to three-fourths of the new Customs and Excise revenue, such additional payment to be distributed per capita.

The Commonwealth to have the right to impose new duties for specific purposes, both on items at present subject to duty, and also on items at present not subject to duty - the Commonwealth Treasurer to retain the whole of the revenue raised thereby.

speech.para: The above three clauses, which were agreed to, were those submitted to the Conference by the right honorable member for Swan. The Conference also agreed that the further consideration of the taking over of the States debts by the Commonwealth should be postponed until the question of distribution of the surplus revenue amongst the States was determined.

talk.start.para: - The honorable gentleman is not surprised at the States being willing to accept that provision?

- Not at all. Of course, those provisions would not be binding on Parliament ; they were adopted subject to ratification by Parliament. With regard to the other question - the continuation of the operation of the Braddon section - it appears very evident from the figures I have quoted this evening that such an arrangement, however desirable to the States, will be quite impossible in view of public expenditure which must be carried out by the Commonwealth. I have been called so suddenly to take the position I now occupy, and Have had so little opportunity of considering this question, that I feel that some time must elapse before my views are thoroughly matured.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - Has the Treasurer correctly stated the position? Is it not a fact that the ex-Treasurer offered the States the surplus out of the, special duties ?
- Yes. The statement I have given has been handed to me by my officers.
- Has the honorable gentleman made any provision for increased allowances to members of this House?

- I am not sorry the honorable member has asked that question, because no one can shut his eyes to the fact that it is very hard for some members to come to this Parliament at all under existing conditions. I understand that this is not a party question. It is one for the consideration of members themselves, and I must say that if honorable members desire the matter to be considered, the Government will afford an early opportunity for that to be done.
- Surely it is a question for their constituents to have an opportunity of considering?

- I have nothing to say about my constituents in that regard, because I expressed my views on many occasions, and so have a large number of honorable members. I have merely made these remarks in answer to a question.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - Is that all the answer to it?

- I shall give another answer very shortly, I believe, but not to-night. I was going to say something about the protective policy. When I have concluded my Financial Statement, I intend, before I sit down, to submit the Tariff, and to give a short explanation of it. Let me say, first, that in a country like Australia - so different from every other country - even if we suffer occasionally a time of depression, caused by climatic conditions, which we cannot control, it would ill become us as a people to take a pessimistic view of the future. We are not in the same category with countries whose development has been carried to the highest pitch; but, on the contrary, we are yet unaware how great are our possibilities. With such an immense country, possessing such great resources, with industries so certain of development, we can afford to be optimistic, and confidently look forward to a prosperous future for the Commonwealth. Honorable members will find in the Tariff, to the preparation of which a great deal of work has been' devoted, a better arrangement of the duties, which are brought under headings with which they are more distinctly associated than in the previous Tariff. Honorable members will find two columns, one showing the general Tariff, and another applying to goods produced or manufactured in the United Kingdom.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - Is there not another column to show the difference between the present duties and the proposed duties?

- Not on this paper, but I shall submit a paper in which that information is given. I have a great deal more information available, but I have kept this copy clean because it is the one on which the duties are to be collected. I desire to refer to the question of iron bounties. Honorable members know that I have tried twice - I think that my honorable colleague has tried once - to pass ah Iron Bounties Bill, but failed. I hope that we may succeed on this occasion. I have an Iron Bounties Bill ready to submit. I have not brought it here to-night, because there is no necessity to submit it now.
- Is that a Bill to provide for a bounty on the production of iron?
- Yes.
- Where does the honorable gentleman expect to get the money from, seeing that, according to his estimates, he expects to have a surplus of only £100,000 ?
- I shall tell the honorable member when I am discussing the question.
- It is only a fair thing that in his Budget the honorable gentleman should tell us where he expects to get the money from.

- Perhaps the honorable member will not object to the way in which I propose to raise the money. I have here a provision to which I wish to call attention. It will be remembered that our previous proposals contained a division - VIa. - which empowered the Minister to recommend, under certain conditions, the imposition of a duty, that is, when a sufficient quantity of raw material was manufactured in the Commonwealth. I have in the Tariff a similar provision with a slightly different heading.

talker.party: REV TAR; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; CP from 1920; IND from 1928
talker.name: MCWILLIAMS, William
Mr McWILLIAMS

talk.start.para: - The Minister proposes to have a duty instead of a bonus?

- I am going to have either a bonus or a duty this time. The Prime Minister is very anxious that I should submit a proposal; for bounties first, because there is no doubt that that has been the course followed in other countries. I want to give honorable members an opportunity of voting on the Bill, but if it is not carried, I shall resort to the duties which are mentioned in Division VIa. The proposal is to levy a duty of 12½ per cent. on pig iron. The duty on other items is a little higher. In Division VIb. I have a provision enumerating most of the manufactures in which pig iron and steel are used. These items are already included at lesser rates in the part of the Tariff which will come into force tomorrow. If the Iron Bounties Bill is not carried, and the imposition of the duties is authorized, then I shall ask the Committee to omit the heading from Division VIb., and bring into operation a duty of 2 per cent. on those items in order to make up for the extra payment on the raw material.
- Do I understand that a duty will be collected on iron to-morrow ?

- I have made provision so that I can get a duty under certain conditions. If a duty is preferred to a bonus, then in the Tariff I have a division from which I can strike out the heading, so there will be an increased duty on the manufactured article, protecting the manufacturer to the extent of 2 per cent.
- It ought to be well considered, anyhow.

- It has been framed in such a way that it will be well considered. I was very much tempted to propose a duty which could be levied forthwith, but I recognised that if we put a duty on the raw material without giving some compensation to the manufacturer we should do a great injustice.
- How much is the duty on pig iron to the manufacturer? Only 1 or 2 per cent. at the outside.
- I have a calculation showing that it is equal to from 1¼ to 2 per cent.
- It is hardly worth talking about.
- I have put on a duty of 2 per cent. to make an equivalent, so that the manufacturer shall not be injured in either case.
- The honorable gentleman is very tender about some manufacturers.
- Can the Minister give an approximate idea of what the amount of the iron bounty will be?
-There is a schedule attached to the Bill. Some items have been struck out, but the bounty is less than was proposed on a' previous occasion.
- What was it then ?

- I do not remember the exact amount; but I think it was nearly £500,000. Perhaps I had better say here that, at the present moment, some negotiations are proceeding in reference to an exchange of the products of the New Hebrides and New Guinea, The negotiations had not advanced sufficiently for me to deal with the matter in my Budget, but the Prime Minister is anxious that the Committee should know that negotiations are proceeding in regard to the products of those and other Pacific Islands. I have a list here which I shall have printed, showing the imports from Great Britain and from foreign countries on which a preference is given. In most cases, where the imports from foreign countries are large, we have given a preference to Great Britain, and I have been advised that, on the items which have been considered, it averages per cent., and that the annual difference in duty payable, between the general Tariff and the preference Tariff, would be between £1,200,000 and £1,300,000.
- Is the Minister reducing the present duties in order to do that?

- Only in one or two cases. For the information of honorable members, especially the protectionist side of the Tariff Commission - I shall also refer to the free-trade side, because they are widely different-
- We shall be very glad to be recognised.
- I am afraid that that is the extent to which I can go.
- That is all I expected.

- I have not had it worked out; but I am inclined to think that, on the whole, the result of the recommendations of the free- trade members of the Tariff Commission would be to reduce the present duties. The number of items on which the proposed Tariff agrees with the recommendations of the other members of that body is 325 out of a total of 444. The number of items on which It does not agree with their recommendations is 82, and the number of new items is 37. There are one or two cases in which the recommendation of the Tariff Commission has been reduced a little. But in most cases we have done what we could to give recognition to the reports to which so much time and labour have been devoted. I do not think that it is necessary to read the paper which I have before me with reference to the preference proposals of the Government, but the following table shows the value of the imports in 1906 of the articles enumerated below from Great Britain and from foreign countries, including British Dominions : -

speech.para: The concessions will, on the basis of our present imports, represent £1,250,000. or 11 J per cent. That is to say, that amount represents the difference in duty between the general Tariff and the preference Tariff ; but as it is expected that the imports from Great Britain will increase in consequence of these preference proposals, it will not be improper to estimate that the concession will amount to, say, £1,500,000, or 1 3 J- per cent.

talk.start.para: - Is that on the basis of the existing Tariff or of the proposed Tariff?
- On the basis of the proposed Tariff.
- Is it conditional on Great Britain giving Australia any concession in return ? ,

- None whatever are asked by us. I wish to add in reference to that question, that I am very sorry that Great Britain cannot see her way clear to give us some preference. When I was in Great Britain on one or two occasions I took the opportunity - and I know that the Prime Minister did also - to say that, although we did not receive the concession that we asked for, or any other concession, from Great Britain, still Australia did not intend to approach this question again from the point of view of bargaining. We shall, however, always be very glad indeed to accept any concession that Great Britain may think fit to give to us.
- Is any preference proposed with any other country than Great Britain ?

- Not in these proposals, but what the honorable member suggests can be done. I have been considering the question in reference to Canada, and when I was in London I had an interview with Sir Wilfrid Laurier and the Canadian Treasurer with regard to it. But it seeme'3 to be almost impossible to arrive at an understanding. Otherwise proposals would have been embodied in the Tariff now submitted. An arrangement can, however, be made with Canada at any time by way of a reciprocal Tariff. The South African Preference Tariff will continue on the same footing as at present.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - Is the honorable gentleman able to state how the preference proposals will affect Great Britain? Are the duties affecting her put up or down ?
- The duties against Great Britain are below those affecting other countries.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - Is it proposed to reduce any duties?
- I will not say whether we are reducing any, but if so they are very few. The point is that the preference to Great Britain takes the form of duties lower than those against other countries.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - Is it proposed to take any duties off for the benefit of Great Britain ?

- I am not sure. I cannot say positively, but I do not wish the honorable member to take that answer as definite. The. British preference proposals of the Government affect 153 items, all of which are important, out of a total of 436 items. We think that that is a fairly reasonable preference to make. I am glad to find, from the cheers of honorable members, that they are in accord with the Government in the action they are taking, and that they also approve of the policy of the Government in not asking for reciprocity from Great Britain in connexion with our preference proposals.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - Does the Minister intend to give us any idea as to the scale or range of the new duties?

- I cannot go into details. There are 245 columns in the new Tariff. I have devoted a considerable amount of work to it during the last week or two, and- 1 am sure that the Committee will not expect me to deal with the question more fully to-night. The Tariff will be circulated at once. I have had a weight on my mind with regard to it for a good many days past. Our proposals have been ready for practically a fortnight. The members of the Government and the officials concerned with this work have had to maintain the greatest secrecy.. I think that we have kept our secret very well ; though I admit that I was almost expecting every morning to see something in the press, and to be compelled, in consequence, to bring down the Tariff in the course of the day.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - What is the average amount of the increases?
- I have not those particulars at my fingers' ends, but I can get the information for the honorable member.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - We ought to have it here.
- The principal thing is that I have brought the' Tariff down and circulated it. It will be something for honorable members lo consider during the next few days.
- Even now the Opposition are not satisfied, though they have been clamouring for the Tariff for the last month !

- If they read the whole of it, they will have more than sufficient food for reflection for to-night. I have to conclude by thanking honorable members . for their consideration and patience in listening to a speech that has occupied nearly two hours. I hope that I have been as concise as was consistent with the nature of the subject, engaged as I have been in the delivery of a Budget which is of unusual importance, having regard to the future of this Commonwealth. I beg to move -
